content: Surface transportation authorization acts fund federal highway and mass transit programs, safety, research, and some rail programs. The most recent authorization, SAFETEA-LU, expired in 2009, leading to a series of extension acts and resolutions due to budget constraints. The highway trust fund, supported by gasoline and diesel taxes, has seen declining revenues in recent years. The Highway Trust Fund (HTF) has faced revenue declines due to economic conditions and improved fuel efficiency, leading to debates on passing a multi-year bill without cutting infrastructure spending, raising gas taxes, or increasing the budget deficit. Other issues like alternative finance, tolling, public-private partnerships, project delivery acceleration, and performance management are also being discussed. The question of equity in federal spending distribution among states remains unresolved given current revenue forecasts. The distribution of federal spending among states is a challenge due to revenue forecasts. The Senate passed MAP-21, reauthorizing surface transportation programs for two years. The House committees reported favorably on H.R. 7, the American Energy and Infrastructure Jobs Act, a five-year bill authorizing $260 billion. H.R. 7 differs from MAP-21 in programmatic content and treatment of the HTF, both reducing programs by two-thirds and free of earmarks. The House passed the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2012, Part II (H.R. 4348) on April 18, 2012, extending surface transportation authorizations through the end of FY2012.
